Positive neurological findings included cogwheel rigidity, resting bilateral tremor (4 per second) in the upper extremities with greater involvement of the right side, bradykinesia, masked facies, a slow gait with small steps, and decreased arm swing. physical_examinations.changes_over_time: There was an exacerbation of parkinsonian symptoms noted before hospitalization, which included deepening depression and increased parkinsonian symptoms.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Cognitive, memory, and intellectual function appeared intact, but marked psychomotor retardation was observed. The patient's mood was depressed with appropriate affect.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Following each ECT treatment, neurological rating scales showed considerable decreases in extrapyramidal symptoms, with a 59% improvement for the Duvoisin scale and a 40% improvement for the Simpson scale noted by the end of the ECT treatments.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: All tests returned to baseline levels, marking a return of parkinsonian signs and severe depression.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: The patient had significantly worsened following ECT, returning to baseline depression and parkinsonism levels.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Although the patient had been started on antiparkinsonian medication, results were approximately the same as those at baseline and the 7-week follow-up.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Continued to be markedly parkinsonian and severely depressed with no significant changes from prior evaluations.
